Unity of Moral Attitudes

Outline of Issues

What unifies all of these moral attitudes as moral attitudes?

They share the same parts.

  1. The Problem of the Menagerie of Moral Attitudes
  2. A Recipe Semantics Solution
  3. An Evolutionary Account of the Structure of Moral Attitudes

Noncognitivism - Moral judgements count as *moral* judgments because of their noncogntive properties.

Example: To judge that it is wrong to kill is to desire that people not kill, that people be blamed for killing, etc.

Recipe Semantics - A characterization of a content in terms of its parts.

Proposal:

  • Moral attitudes are attitudes constructed with moral concepts.
  • Moral concepts are defined in terms of their use in certain contexts.
  • In other contexts, they have no meaning-characterizing use.

Spandrel Context: A context in which a concept does not have a meaning-characterizing use, but which arise because of the laws of cognitive syntax.

  • Logical

    • It is not wrong to collect trophies of extinct species.
    • Human beings either have a special moral status or we should not be testing cosmetics on animals.
    • Everything you did today was worse than the thing you did before it.

  • Attitudinal

    • Supposing that it is wrong not to make small personal sacrifices to save lives.
    • Wondering whether it is wrong to eat animals.
    • Wishing that it wasn't wrong to lie to your mother.

  • Other

    • If it had been wrong to bring children into this world, we would not have done it.
    • Wrongs are a stain upon the moral character of decent people.
    • You should (rationally) keep track of what you shouldn't (morally) do.

So what do all these attitudes have in common?

  • Moral Concepts

      Distinctive orthographic form.

      Distinctive role in some contexts.

  • Nipple Analogy

    • Nipples have a functional characterization.
    • Nipples occur in contexts in which they lack that function.
    • They can be identified by sharing non-functional properties with other things that share them.
    • In these contexts, they are spandrels.

  • Spandrel Context

    • Moral concepts have a functional characterization.
    • Moral concept tokens occur in contexts where they lack that function.
    • They can be identified by sharing orthographic properties with concepts that have that function.
    • In these contexts, they are spandrels.
